title: 108_hr4019
content: Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization is addressed in Section 1. Congress finds that good health and access to high-quality health information and services are crucial for public health. Participation in international health cooperation forums is important due to the potential spread of infectious diseases like HIV, tuberculosis, and malaria. Taiwan's population of 23,500,000 people is significant. Taiwan's population of 23,500,000 people is greater than that of 3/4 of the member states in the World Health Organization. Taiwan has achieved high life expectancy levels, low maternal and infant mortality rates, and eradicated infectious diseases. Taiwan has achieved high life expectancy levels, low maternal and infant mortality rates, and eradicated infectious diseases like cholera, smallpox, the plague, and polio. The United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and Taiwan's health agencies collaborate closely on public health issues. Taiwan is willing to provide financial and technical assistance for international health activities supported by the WHO. On January 14, 2001, Taiwan sent 2 rescue teams to El Salvador after an earthquake, providing $200,000 in relief aid. Taiwan is willing to assist in international health activities supported by the WHO. Foreign Affairs donated $200,000 in relief aid to the Salvadoran Government. The World Health Assembly allowed observers from various organizations to participate in its activities. The United States declared its support for Taiwan's participation in international organizations in the 1994 Taiwan Policy Review. Public Law 106-137 mandated a report to Congress on executive branch efforts. Public Law 106-137 mandated a report to Congress on efforts to support Taiwan's participation in international organizations, specifically the WHO. President Bush expressed support for Taiwan's meaningful involvement in the WHO due to the benefits it can bring to Taiwan and global health. President Bush expressed support for Taiwan's participation in international organizations, specifically the WHO, emphasizing the importance of Taiwan's voice being heard and finding ways for Taiwan to benefit and contribute to the WHO. Secretary of Health and Human Services Tommy Thompson announced the US government's support for Taiwan's efforts to gain observership status at the World Health Assembly, emphasizing the importance of public health for the people of Taiwan. In response to appeals from the United Nations and the United States, the Government of the Republic of China on Taiwan donated $1,000,000 to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria in December 2002. In 2003, Taiwan experienced 84 deaths due to the outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS). Avian influenza, also known as bird flu, has resurfaced in Asia, with reported strains in various countries including China, Cambodia, Indonesia, Japan, Pakistan, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, Vietnam, and Laos. The importance of allowing all people access to the WHO is emphasized by the SARS and avian influenza outbreaks, as disease knows no boundaries. With globalization accelerating the spread of infectious diseases, it is crucial for all, including Taiwan, to participate in international health organizations like the WHO. The Secretary of Health and Human Services acknowledged the need for effective public health among all peoples during the 2003 World Health Assembly meeting. The Secretary of State is authorized to initiate a US plan to endorse Taiwan for observer status at the World Health Assembly in Geneva, Switzerland. The Secretary of State is instructed to implement a plan to endorse Taiwan for observer status at the World Health Assembly in Geneva. The Secretary of State must also submit a report to Congress describing the US plan for Taiwan's observer status within 30 days of the enactment of this Act and annually thereafter by April 1. The Secretary of State is directed to endorse Taiwan for observer status at the World Health Assembly in Geneva. A report to Congress must be submitted annually, detailing efforts to promote Taiwan's bid for observer status and steps to be taken at the next meeting. The House of Representatives passed the bill on April 21, 2004.
